content:
Existentialist literature doesn't necessarily reject the idea of objective truth altogether, but it does challenge the traditional view that objective truth is the only valid way to understand the world. Instead, existentialists emphasize that subjective experience and individual interpretation are equally important in shaping our understanding of reality.

Existentialists believe that objective truth cannot fully capture the complexity of the human experience, and that the search for objective truth can actually be a form of escape from the uncertainties and anxieties of life. They argue that subjective experience is just as important in shaping our understanding of the world, and that individuals must take responsibility for their own lives and choices.

In this sense, existentialist literature can be seen as a response to the limitations of traditional philosophy, which emphasized rationality and objective truth above all else. Instead, existentialist literature emphasizes the importance of personal experience and individual interpretation in shaping our understanding of the world, and encourages us to confront the uncertainties and anxieties of life head-on.
